Name: TERBUTHYLAZINE
Description: Terbutylazine is a diamino-1,3,5-triazine that is N-tert-butyl-N'-methyl-1,3,5-triazine-2,4-diamine substituted by a chloro group at position 6. It has a role as a herbicide, an environmental contaminant and a xenobiotic. It is a diamino-1,3,5-triazine and a chloro-1,3,5-triazine. It is functionally related to a 6-chloro-1,3,5-triazine-2,4-diamine.

plant_concentrations.References: Robinson RC, Dunham RJ; Weed Res 22 (4): 223-6 (1982)
plant_concentrations.Value: (14)C-labeled terbuthylazine was applied to the surface of soil columns 100 mm deep and uptake by oat seedlings measured for approx 24 days after germination following 2 contrasting rainfall treatments. Attempts were made to predict measured uptake on the basis of mass flow theory given also measurements of transpiration rates, water, rooting, and herbicide distribution profiles in the soil, and soil adsorption characteristics.

plant_translocations.content: The study investigated the uptake of eight organic xenobiotics from soil by plants in a closed aerated laboratory soil-plant system, allowing the differentiation between uptake via the roots and via the leaves after evaporation. Residues of all tested chemicals were detected in roots and shoots, but the uptake pathways varied. Hexachlorobenzene (HCB) and octachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (OCDD) showed no translocation between roots and shoots. The s-triazine terbuthylazine was predominantly taken up by the roots and translocated to the shoots. Herbicides chlorotoluron and trichloroacetic acid (TCA) were transported bidirectionally. The uptake of trichloroethylene (TCE), chlorobenzene, and methyl-t-butylether (MTBE) was primarily through foliar uptake.
plant_translocations.reference: Schroll, R., Bierling, B., Cao, G., Dörfler, U., Lahaniati, M., Langenbach, T., ... & Winkler, R. (1994). Uptake pathways of organic chemicals from soil by agricultural plants. Chemosphere, 28(2), 297-303.

method.Plant Grown Condition: The laboratory test system had a closed aerated system, where plants were grown in contaminated soil (900g fresh weight, 16% water) able to take up chemicals from both soil and air. Non-contaminated soil (450g fresh weight, 16% water) was also present, covered to prevent air contamination, allowing root uptake only. Air was drawn through the system.
method.Chemical Preparation: Terbuthylazine-~C 2 were extracted from soil with methanol in a soxhlet for about 48 hrs.
method.Other Information: The experimental duration was 7 days. Plant and soil analysis methods are described for extraction,
